awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Open Access Blended Learning Modules for Teaching Laboratory Methods: Developing Scientific Skills for Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
The lack of appropriate instructional materials at the undergraduate level for laboratory techniques presents a significant barrier to increasing student access to and knowledge of analytical skills necessary to succeed in the geosciences and other STEM fields.  This project will create and evaluate five open access online learning modules for laboratory methods and scientific inquiry skills.  These materials will initially be evaluated in courses at a four-year university (JMU) and a minority-serving two-year college (NOVA).  The community-based review, evaluation, contribution, and further testing of these modules in various types of classrooms will create a forum for sharing ideas among geoscience and STEM faculty who wish to incorporate analytical methods into courses using robust peer-reviewed online teaching resources.  The modular format will provide flexibility for instructors to use as few or as many units as needed for a specific course or student research experience.  

Five learning modules will be created that represent commonly available analytical methods as well as techniques available at both JMU and NOVA.  These units will include gas and water plumbing, petrographic microscopes, thin sectioning equipment, energy-dispersive spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and Raman and infrared spectroscopies.  Scientific inquiry skills will be embedded into the content modules, and will include creating and testing protocols, evaluating data quality and error, and synthesizing data.  To benefit the larger geosciences and STEM community, the modules will be published on an open educational resource (OER) courseware site.  Module structure and content will align with active, inquiry-based learning theories, and will include video mini-lectures, individual and group quizzes and assignments, expository materials in video or animation formats, video tours of equipment and laboratories, and instructor resources.  This project will improve geosciences and STEM learning by establishing effective practices for integrating open educational resources into research-based instructional units in geoscience and STEM courses involving the use of analytical equipment.  The assessment plan will include formative and summative evaluations of student learning and attitudes within required and elective courses in geosciences and STEM at JMU and NOVA, as well as module reviews by geoscience community members outside of these institutions.  Evaluation will focus on the effects of open educational resources and a blended learning course format upon student retention of analytical methods and instrumentation skills, student mastery of scientific inquiry skills, and student attitude and competencies towards conducting research with analytical equipment.  The protocol established by this study will be used to create additional modules on other analytical techniques in the future, and will be a template the STEM community may use to develop other online learning resources.

Project Outcomes Report  NSF Award #1611917

Project Title: Collaborative Research: Open Access Blended Learning Modules for Teaching Laboratory Methods: Developing Scientific Skills for Undergraduates

Recipient Organization: Northern Virginia Community College

Project/Grant Period: 7/01/2016 ? 6/30/2022

PI: Ritu Kansal

This project created online Open Educational Resources (OER) modules for lab techniques to support scientific inquiry and analytical skills in undergraduate STEM education. Northern Virginia Community College (NOVA) and James Madison University (JMU) worked in collaboration to create and publish these modules as Analytical Methods in Geosciences at the Lumen Learning site, an OER Education company. The YouTube Channel, Analytical Methods in Geosciences (AmiGEO), with Creative Commons CC-by license hosts the closed-captioned video clips produced by NOVA and JMU. 

NOVA especially produced 34 videos explaining the basic theory and applications of scanning electron microscope (SEM), energy-dispersive spectroscopy studies (EDS), and techniques of making thin sections of the rocks.

The SEM and EDS series of videos introduces STEM users to the basics and applications of SEMs, including sample preparation and loading, SEM imaging and chemical analysis by EDS.

The thin-section series of videos detail the steps from rock to thin section. The videos walk the users through creating samples using the cutting, grinding and polishing machines in the lab, and include sample mounting procedures. 

Teaching is the best way to learn.This project provided a unique opportunity for the students to get research experiences and dive deeper by teaching others. Students participated actively in designing lab exercises on applications of SEM and EDS, based on Process-Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL). Engaging students in teaching enhances analytical skills, and also improves student efficacy, communication skills and confidence. 

NOVA produced an online open database website for geology students which provides clean access to the tools students need to identify minerals, such as physical properties and optical data.  Images of thin sections in several formats are used and include high-resolution photo micrographs, GigaPan images, and video micrographs. The website is very informative and easy to use.

https://blogs.nvcc.edu/mineralogy/

NOVA and JMU have been using these open learning modules in their courses of Chemistry and Geology. Other than publications, the NOVA Annual STEM fairs and Night of Science events provide a great platform to disseminate the knowledge and results of this project. NOVA hosts a community outreach event called Night of Science every semester where hundreds of visitors come to learn about science and technology through several demonstrations and hands-on activities. The students use these modules to prepare for these events for discussions with the people on how the SEM and EDS work and the broader scope of their applications in STEM research and education.

The NOVA team collaborated with the JMU team in information exchange on the content resources, development of modules, technical aspects and assessment interviews of the users in OER environment. The feedback from users indicate that such open educational resources will improve the learning and teaching as they allow repeated viewing, better visual description,save time and flexibility to modify contents according to the needs. They are even more important in conditions like COVID -19 pandemic when most of the learning was online.

By creating these open modules and applying best practice of Universal Design principles, NOVA hopes to expand the equitable access to STEM instructional resources. More students with diverse backgrounds will choose STEM majors in all institutions beyond NOVA and JMU. The instructors will be able to create new educational activities and collaborations for research, teaching and training. Early exposure to STEM research experiences develops long-term student engagement and will help in retaining STEM related careers.This project can serve as a template for developing OER for other STEM methods and studies. 

Publications:

Mengason MJ, Buecheler J, Rohrback RC, Kansal R, Poe T, Pourtalebi B. Educational Resources For Early Inclusion of Analytical Techniques in Undergraduate Education. Poster presented at: Fall meeting of American Geophysical Union; 2020 Dec 1-17; Chicago, IL & Online Everywhere

Johnson, E.A., Liu, J.C., Mao, J., and Kansal, R. (2018) "Developing a protocol for filming, editing, and captioning videos in the laboratory." Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs. , v.50 , 2018 doi: 10.1130/abs/2018AM-315964

 Liu, J. C., Johnson, E., Mao, J., Kansal, R., & Adams, C. "Designing a multimodal open access ?lab methods in geosciences? textbook -An action research study." Paper presented at 2019 American Educational Research Association (AERA) Annual Meeting, Toronto, Canada. , 2019

Johnson, E.A., Liu, J.C., Mao, J., and Kansal, R. "Accessibility and user experience in design and development of an open access Analytical Methods in Geosciences (AMiGEO) Textbook." Abstract ED51I-0736 presented at 2018 Fall Meeting, AGU, Washington, D.C., 10-14 Dec. , 2018

 Juhong Liu, Jin Mao, Elizabeth Johnson, Shelley Jaye, and Ritu Kansal "Design and Assessment of Deep and Active Learning in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Education" Juried Conference Paper , 2017 , p.www.hkaec P4-3
